push_data.commit_title: Use variable for meson build dir

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
I don't know how to install debug packages on Debian/Ubuntu-based distros, I haven't really used those in the last 15 years. [Search around](https://www.google.com/search?q=ubuntu+install+debug+packages) or ask the Pop!_OS support folks please.

Once debug packages for gnote, gtk4 and glib2 are installed: install Sysprof, run it, press the big record button, do the slow thing with gnote, save the result from Sysprof and zip it. The rest if you are curious is all in the guides I linked above.

target_title: All notes gone after gnote crashed. Can't find a way to restore notes from sync

note.body:
Replied in [the forum thread](https://discourse.gnome.org/t/restore-previous-notes-db/25618/4) now. I hope that helps.

As for this ticket here, since it's presumably not caused by gnote itself / not a bug _in gnote_, I'd suggest closing this ticket.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body: I can try to debug on Pop!_OS (kinda Ubuntu) if you tell me what exactly I need to do.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
This is interesting, and my hunch is that if it's related to the large number of _matches_ (rather than the large number of total notes searchable) then this might indicate a UI performance bottleneck with the listview widgets or highlighting or something like that, rather than an issue with the search backend.

Until someone profiles that with sysprof however, this is only wild intuition guesswork that may be entirely wrong.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body: Yes, Yury, this is also what I'm seeing, if I just type o, it hangs for a very long time.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
> I will also add: I see no reason why search couldn't be fast on 2000 gnote files in theory. [LocalSearch](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/) is able to do full-text search on my entire documents collection (which has over 250,000 files) in less than 0.1 second.

You're right, the search is generally fast: as I said, if I type the whole word, the results appear almost immediately, even though the number of files to search is the same. The problem is the large number of matches. As I said, if I type just one letter, say `o`, it hangs. On the other hand, if I type a _rare_ letter, `z`, it somehow works, with a slight glitch.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
Right, it's just the search, that's why I was in doubt. On the other hand, I was lucky enough to have @gme seconding me, so now I'm sure that the problem is definitely reproducible.

But to be precise: it's not the search being slow, it's something related to the number of matches (see the thread above).

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body: Some time ago, some of the other slowness was fixed to be a bit better.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body: Also, just to be sure I'm understanding the scope of the problem correctly, as you are the original reporter of this ticket: this is only about search being slow, not viewing/editing individual notes, right?

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
> I'm hearing that you're not yet having the issues Yuri and I am having. […]
> 
> Hopefully in a few more years your notes will grow bigger and then you'll reconsider.

I've been using Tomboy/gnote since 2009 and I only have 170 notes in it, so at this point I don't think the notespocalypse will happen on my end; I dodged the issue completely by having most of my notes being plain markdown files strewn across the filesystem (part of the reason behind this is that I did not want to be tied to a particular app). That's cheating, I know.

However, it gives me a unique perspective: I can confirm from experience that it is possible, because Nautilus' "Search Everywhere" mode (using only Tracker/"LocalSearch") can _easily_ handle searches _in the contents_ of my 250 000 files, _in realtime as I type,_ in less than a tenth of a second without lagging, _on a 7200rpm SATA HDD with a 15-years-old CPU._ From that experience, I find it hard to believe gnote couldn't search through 1/100th of that without breaking a sweat.

> Sorry I can't send you my notefiles due to security issues.

Again I would rather encourage you to go through the effort of profiling yourself on your machine with your specific hardware. As long as you have the debug symbols installed for gnote and its dependencies, Sysprof 47+ is fun and easy to use, it takes a few seconds to make such a capture, zip it and attach it.

Otherwise, if you were able to somehow find a way to anonymize a spare copy of your notes from `~/.local/share/gnote/` (maybe with some script replacing the copy's contents by gibberish) and share them in a tarballed/zipped format, I would be willing to try to sysprof this for you if you are unable to.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body: Jeff, I'm hearing that you're not yet having the issues Yuri and I am having.  Sorry I can't send you my notefiles due to security issues.  And while you are correct with enough time spent indexing, super-large datasets can be quickly searched with various methods.  As for me, i'm old-school.  KISS: Keep it simple stupid mentality.  While having it quickly show results as you type the next character works pretty good (and is "cool") for small datasets like for a phone contact list, it's really not appropriate for large datasets where more, and sometimes MUCH more, time is required to produce a results set with each character typed.  Thanks for chiming in.  Hopefully in a few more years your notes will grow bigger and then you'll reconsider.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
I will also add: I see no reason why search couldn't be fast on 2000 gnote files in theory. [LocalSearch](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/) is able to do full-text search on my entire documents collection (which has over 250,000 files) in less than 0.1 second.

That's why I'd recommend you profile this with [Sysprof](https://developer.gnome.org/documentation/tools/sysprof.html) with full debug symbols installed, on a Linux distro that has frame pointers enabled (Fedora, Ubuntu 24.04 and newer, Arch, etc.), before even considering disabling the search delay, which would be hiding the problem under the rug.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
From what I can see with the Gtk Inspector, gnote correctly uses a 500ms `search-delay` property on its GTK [SearchEntry](https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/class.SearchEntry.html) widget, instead of the default way-too-aggressive 150ms. However, if the search engine backend can't keep up with large amounts of notes, if you don't type fast enough, even 500ms might be a bit short, I guess.

There does not seem to be an explicit "infinite search-delay" situation mentioned in the docs, but I could imagine these two or three possible approaches:  
_when the number of notes exceeds a certain amount,_ gnote could automatically either:

* Dynamically lengthen that `search-delay` property (to 1000 ms, 1500 ms, 2000 ms, etc.)…
  * based on the total number of notes in the collection;
  * based on the search query length (i.e. wait much longer if there is less than 4 characters typed)… however this is more difficult to achieve, because they you must not use the `search-delay` property anymore, you have to do your own internal dynamic length-based variable timer implementation.
* Ignore the delay-based `search-changed` signal completely, and instead connect only to the `search-started` and `search-stopped` signals that occur on manual keyboard input actions. This is just a guess on my part, I have never used those, but that's how I interpret the GTK docs.

---

But fundamentally, it would be better if the search backend's performance was constantly fast no matter how many notes you have, and the only way to achieve that is for you to sysprof it as I mentioned above, and give us the data to figure out what makes it slow. If it can be optimized to eliminate the issue entirely, that's a much nicer outcome. Here is [a general guide](https://fedoramagazine.org/performance-profiling-in-fedora-linux/) about how Sysprof works and how to interpret results.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
I also have this exact same problem.  

The software algorithm for the search box has a timer running.  If you don't type fast enough then it starts searching. 

I don't always type fast enough and it wastes lots of time searching for things I don't want it to search for.  

It would be good if there was a switch to turn this behavior off so that once I'm done entering the search string I could hit enter to start the searching.  Or to turn this timed auto-enter behavior off completely.  I don't see that it saves more than a single enter key stroke and it is much more grief with it than without it.

target_title: Gnote search gets sluggish with lots of notes / matches

note.body:
I have the same performance issue on version `47.0`: I have 2100+ notes, and many of them are pretty long. And whenever I start typing in the search field, `gnote` stops responding. The expected result at this moment would be at least 100K matches, which doesn't make too much sense but that is what makes `gnote` slow. On the other hand, if I paste the whole word at once instead of typing (so that there are only a few matches), all works fine.

My problem is only with search, not the general slowness with lots of content; therefore, it might be a separate ticket.

target_title: Pressing Tab key does nothing

note.body:
Hey I know the issue was closed, yet I'd like to advocate for restoring the previously working tab behavior:

When the user is pressing tab in a regular line, a tab character will be inserted.

When the user is pressing tab in a bulleted list item, the item's indent is increased.

When the user types a `-` or `*` character at the beginning of a line, the line is turned into a list item.

I don't exactly recall at exactly which version the tabulation feature vanished from gnote, but I have tons of notes with tabs in them, and they still render just fine. I just cannot insert new tab characters with the keyboard. I can even copy/paste tab characters into gnote and they work.

So I'm reopening this issue and am asking the gnote project maintainers that if they decide to remove tabulation, to close it again, stating their plan.

target_title: Pressing Tab key does nothing
Pressing Tab key does nothing
Pressing Tab key does nothing

note.body: I agree, for consistency sake pressing tab should start bullet list, given that Tab and Shift+Tab increase/decrease depth in a bullet list, including complete removal of bullet.

target_title: Pressing Tab key does nothing

note.body:
It actually does something when redacting a list. Like you type "- blah" or "* foorbar", then return, it formats as a list and then with tab you can increase or decrease indentation.

But I agree this seems a bit off when out of a list _(also having to first hit return, then backspace to erase 2nd line and go back to 1st element to increase its indent is a bit weird; but I'm not sure how this could be correctly improved)_.
It may be to enter tab char when out of a list (this could also mean having to have a setting to specify tab width...).

I believe it was the case in previous versions? Like maybe v43, I remember having some notes where I manually set indentation without needing to make some lists.

note.body: Re: Page Up/Down: yes, you're right, that was my mistake, thanks!

target_title: Feature request: standard tabbed application shortcut keys

note.body:
Nautilus also has those behavior (except for Ctrl+Click, but Ctrl+return work instead. Maj+Return also open in new window, as in web browsers)_(also except Ctrl+[1-9] and Ctrl+Shift+W)_

I don't think this is a "standard" but really usual for users to have that kind of shortcut whenever tabs are present, even though they're not always exactly consistent between apps (what a standard would be).

Maybe the Gnome project would define some sort of internal UX standard across its apps? _(my two cents, don't know much about Gnome working)(and also not saying gnote dev should take care of that, just a vague idea!)_


Also, if implementing Ctrl+[1-9], one has to take care of input mechanism as not every keyboard layouts gives numbers for this range of key presses.
(like on French AZERTY, we would get « &,é,",',(,... »). That's a common mistake, even though I've never developed that kind of thing and imagine that moderns libraries offers consistent ways for this :)

(also, for me, Page up/down are swapped (Up move to the left, down to the right)(firefox, nautilus, chromium) ; not that important, but I wondered if you mistyped or if this is defined by some sort of locales, or..?)

Cheers
